steps.title: A Mongolian spot is a flat, blue birthmark on a newborn’s backside.
steps.content: A Mongolian spot is a flat, blue birthmark on a newborn’s backside. A Mongolian spot is a type of pigmented birthmark that is caused by a buildup of pigment cells, or melanocytes, underneath the skin. These spots typically appear on the lower back or buttocks and can be blue, green, or gray. [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Mongolian spots are also called congenital dermal melanocytosis. The spots are either present at birth or appear a few weeks after birth. While Mongolian spots can look like bruises, they are harmless birthmarks. They are not associated with any diseases or conditions. [16] X Research source Most spots fade by the time children are 3 to 5 years old. In rare cases, they remain permanent throughout adulthood. [17] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Mongolian spots are most common in people of Asian, Native American, Hispanic, East Indian, and African descent. The spots are typically irregularly shaped and can be small or large.

steps.title: In China, Mongolian spots are associated with Songzi Guanyin.
steps.content: In China, Mongolian spots are associated with Songzi Guanyin. According to Chinese myth, babies receive Mongolian spots from the fertility goddess Songzi Guanyin. [18] X Research source In some legends, Songzi Guanyin slaps babies to tell them it’s time to be born and speed up labor. In other myths, Songzi Guanyin has to kick the baby out because they refuse to leave their mother’s womb, which results in a bruise-like mark.

steps.title: In Korea, babies receive Mongolian spots from Samsin Halmeoni.
steps.content: In Korea, babies receive Mongolian spots from Samsin Halmeoni. Korean myths about Mongolian spots are similar to Chinese myths. According to their legends, the child-bearing goddess Samsin Halmeoni gives babies Mongolian spots as she smacks them to help them get out of their mother’s womb.

steps.title: In Mongolia, Mongolian spots signify good health.
steps.content: In Mongolia, Mongolian spots signify good health. To Mongolians, having this birthmark is a sign that you are full of life and vigor. It’s believed to give you the strength to face challenges head-on and keep moving forward. [19] X Research source

steps.title: In Japan, Mongolian spots symbolize immaturity.
steps.content: In Japan, Mongolian spots symbolize immaturity. Mongolian spots refer to the Japanese idiom Shiri ga aoi which translates to “To have a blue butt.” This means that someone is immature or lacks experience.

steps.title: In Africa, Mongolian spots represent nobility and royalty.
steps.content: In Africa, Mongolian spots represent nobility and royalty. According to African beliefs, Mongolian spots symbolize your destiny to be a great leader. It is a sign of your royal heritage and divine purpose to guide and help others. [20] X Research source

steps.title: In India, Mongolian spots signify luck and prosperity.
steps.content: In India, Mongolian spots signify luck and prosperity. Having a Mongolian spot is considered a very good omen in India. This spot is thought to bestow you with blessings and help you reach success in life. [21] X Research source

steps.title: To Native Americans, Mongolian spots signify a spiritual connection.
steps.content: To Native Americans, Mongolian spots signify a spiritual connection. In Native American legends, these spots are a physical representation of your connection with your ancestors. This connection is believed to bring you good fortune and wisdom. [22] X Research source
